title: At close of business on 16 September 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 29 July 2020?
preds: There is extremely little room for the Fed to lower interest rates following the drastic rate cuts in the spring. With little to no increase in inflation and spending still impacted from the ongoing pandemic, I find it all but certain the Fed will stay their current course.

New policy, but no changes now:
https://www.bankrate.com/banking/federal-reserve/fomc-what-to-expect/

With the Federal Funds Rate already being so low, it is unlikely that it will be going much lower. It is also unlikely that the rate will increase since the inflation rate is already so low and the continuing issue of COVID. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-13/fed-s-guidance-catches-up-with-powell-s-new-strategy-week-ahead?sref=DWzi38c2
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3613500-feds-meeting-statement-likely-to-reflect-inflation-averaging-shift

On July 29, 2020, the Federal Funds Rate Range decision stood at a range of 0%-0.25%.  Since March 16, 2020, as of today, that level has continued.  On Friday, September 4, 2020, the Chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Jerome Powell, gave an interview to NPR <https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=909590044&live=1> in which he forecasted that because inflation rates has continuously undershoted its target rate, and because it is expected that a return to pre-COVID employment levels could take more than a year, interest rates will have to continue to be low to support economic activity for an extended period of time.  Additionally, Powell, before that interview, indicated that the US Fed was willing to tolerate an inflation rate above its 2% rate <https://www.forbes.com/sites/advisor/2020/08/27/fed-changes-inflation-stance-powell/#49f4d1d24686>, which because of the inverse relationship between inflation and the US interest rate set by the US Federal Funds Rate, as a result of the system of fractional reserves <https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/12/inflation-interest-rate-relationship.asp#:~:text=There%20is%20a%20general%20tendency,to%20have%20an%20inverse%20relationship.&text=In%20general%2C%20when%20interest%20rates,economy%20slows%20and%20inflation%20decreases.> supports the notion that no increase in the upper-limit of the US Federal Funds rate range is on the horizon.  Thus, I see no reason for the FED to increase the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range on September 16, 2020.  Moreover, because of Chairman Powell’s skepticism on negative interest rates in the US <https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/why-the-us-has-shunned-negative-interest-rates/2020/05/13/50a9a0c4-951f-11ea-87a3-22d324235636_story.html>, it is highly unlikely that the FED will lower interest rates below 0% in the near future.  Thus, my forecast is that on September 16, 2020 the FED will keep the upper limit of the US Federal Funds rate range on 0.25%.

Jerome Powell has said repeatedly that he does not support negative rates, and with a current rate of .25% there is little room for the rate to decrease. More than that however, It would seem highly unlikely that the Fed would decide to begin pushing rates back up just as the economy has started to recover.

The federal fund rate is at its lowest in history, there is little thought that it will go lower. However, it is to soon to raise it during the pandemic. Its currently at a sweet spot. Therefore it will not be changed.
After the "Big Bang" reduction in March there is no further necessity to change it again now.

https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/interest-rate .
on 29th July 2020 the fed fund rate was 0.25%. we can see from the data of us fed fund rate from 1971 to 2020 that 0.25%  is the lowest fed fund rate. As it was never reduced less than that , fed fund rate remain unchanged.

The Federal Reserve has a dual mandate to optimize relationship between inflation and employment.  While this relationship, the Phillips curve, has been flattening it is still one of the important considerations when setting the target range for the federal funds rate.  Employment has not recovered enough to consider moving along it. When the rates were lowered in March from 1-1.25% to 0-.25%, the Fed was attempting to prevent an unemployment and liquidity crisis.  In the absence of any more fiscal stimulus, I think it is very likely that the Fed will maintain its current course as described by chairman Powell.
No setting of expectations for adjustments happening.

“The Committee expects to maintain its target range until it is confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve its maximum employment and price stability goals.”  While the upper limit of the Federal Reserve’s target range has changed frequently since 2016, based on the Committee’s stand and the fact that the economy will not be significantly improved by September 2020, I believe the limit will remain stagnant to support the credit needs of households.
https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/monetary20200315a.htm
I still think "Lower" deserves 1%, but the economy is rallying and I want to muss up the crowd's hair a little.

The current range is the same as it was in 2009, during the Great Recession. At 0-0.25%, it is nearly impossible to lower it further, and it is equally as improbable that the economy will rebound to an extent large enough to warrant an increase. Powell, in setting the rate range in March, also said that negative rates are not appropriate for US policy, though it is possible he will change his position in the future.

Overall, investors have every expectation that the Fed will keep rates steady at their upcoming meeting; earnings season has been relatively buoyant, and the market is reacting less to that than to potential news on vaccines/drug trials, covid infection rates, and various cross-border geopolitical tensions.

I assume the FED will be forced to explore the negative yield territory before 29 July 2020 (it's no real difference of threat to a wealth pool, the Swiss National Bank made it long ago). So from 29 July 2020 there are two (I confess slightly crazy) scenarios: a) the situation on the markets will be so dire and gloomy that neither the first step down into negative territory nor the continuous and ever expanded interventions through "Quantitative Easing" and expansion of the FED's balance in exchange for corporate bonds, stocks and all sorts of assets will prevent the short term money market from experiencing a demand shock for short term low rate instruments, which leads to a jump in market yields as a risk premium and threats for money market investment funds to "break the buck" for the first time since 2008/2009.
in a reaction, the FED may either try to add fuel to the fire by further lowering FED funds rate, in a lack of choice. Or they see that the markets have been by a large proportion overreact having been caught on the wrong foot and try to calm down markets, try to become more predictable again and thus will increase FED funds rate span to a "normal" 0.00 to 0.25-span. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-06-16/harvard-s-rogoff-negative-rates-should-be-on-the-table-for-fed-video
Negative rates unlikely as they have not been very successful in other countries. Fed has other tools it will continue to use.
Just a guess. Don’t know shit about finance.

“We’re not even thinking about thinking about raising rates,” Fed Chairman Jerome Powell told reporters. Given how low current rates are you'd have to imagine they will hold at this rate for some time.
Kind of hard to go lower, don’t see it going higher.
Guess we are going to be seeing lower rates for the next 18 months or so.

No way in frack are they going to raise rates. Not in a recession. It took them eight years to raise rates after the 2008 crash. Powell has made it clear they don't want to go negative and will likely do much more QE before considering negative rates. If they go negative I don't think it will be by September.
Fed is very likely to continue to maintain its current path in the near term as they have done their job of stabilising the financial markets
The economy will not recover fast enough to warrant a rate hike, but Powell has also made it clear the Fed has no intention of creating negative rates.

The economy is going to be sputtering through the summer as we have regional waves of COVID, with stay-at-home orders, restrictions to travel and a selection of other limiting actions. Unemployment will be high due to lack of seasonal jobs and once unemployment insurance runs out, that will be whole 'nother mess. [1,2] As such, while rates can't quite go any lower, they are unlikely to be higher by September.  [1] https://ktvo.com/news/coronavirus/vast-cutbacks-in-jobs-and-spending-before-any-summer-rebound
[2] https://www.vox.com/2020/5/12/21254481/v-shaped-recovery-unlikely

Economic implications of coronavirus, particularly for the banking system, will worsen over the coming months due to increase in layoffs, then rental arrears and mortgage defaults (including commercial and residential). There will be further downward pressure on stock markets, employment, etc., and political pressure to keep rates low until year end (after the Presidential election).

Looks like Federal Reserve plans to keep rates on hold until economy recovers: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/08/fed-releases-minutes-from-meeting-where-it-took-rates-to-zero-because-of-coronavirus.html

Rates are set to keep inflation in check. With high unemployment and recession on the horizon due to COVID-19 the financial pressures will be deflationary, not inflationary, pointing towards lowering rates or keeping them the same.

The 150bps cut in March was a direct response to the coronavirus threat. The Fed looks at maximum employment as one of its goals and this is unlikely to get close to comfortable levels anytime soon. It is most likely the Fed will wait with adjustments in the Fed funds rate until it becomes clearer how the coronavirus affects the US economy.

1. Election year and the fed has already been pressured toward lower rates.
2. Q2 GDP growth will be strongly negative. The fed will not raise rates.
3. There is some discussion re a resurgence of Covid, the fed will want some insurance.
Inflation should eventually come rolling in hard, but this is too soon for fed funds rate to go up.

I think inflation is a very important topic. As we are in a deflationary shock (demand side) with massive FED interventions, I think inflation is not very likely. But  we can have a Supply side shock that tiger inflation. In the other hand we have few margin for lower the rates without enter in the stagnation zone. Both outcomes are possible but I think it will take time. This is a useful link: https://blogs.uoregon.edu/timduyfedwatch/

It is currently 0-25 percent.  This was its lowest point in the data I found and happened in December 2008.  I doubt the high end (.25) could go lower since they adjust in .25 percent increments.  The rate remained 25 percent until 2015.   The current recession should be far worse.  Therefore, it is hard to imagine them raising the rate during this second great depression so the current rate should prevail for some time.  https://apps.newyorkfed.org/markets/autorates/fed%20funds https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/openmarket.htm
We are in the sweet spot. Why would they move it?
Believe Powell when he said it may be kept at zero or near zero for years.

The target rate as of May 1 is .25% - 1.5% lower than a month ago.  I do not see the rate rising significantly before the end of July, it may even go lower if the current economic situation persists.  If so it is not likely to be lower than this in September.  
I also wouldn't expect it to move higher between July and September, due to fears of 2nd wave of COVID in the fall (and due to the election).  It will likely remain low for some time because it will take a long time for economy to recover.

September should be a crucial month for the economy, between first wave of pandemic and presumably on cups of second wave. Effect of slowdown from unemployment, consumer spending, businesses able to reopen and reinvent strategies should be more notable. Also effect on imports of products and needed materials could be felt more around this time.
